sen.e: In this legend, Okuninushi is visited by a small god from across the ocean, who would not reveal his name to anybody and whose name nobody knows.

sen.e: Wishing to know his name, a toad sends for Kuebiko, who is believed to know everything about the world, but is told that Kuebiko was unable to walk.

sen.j: 神名の「クエビコ」は「崩え彦」、体が崩れた男の意で、雨風にさらされて朽ち果てたかかしを表現したものである。
sen.e: The name of the god, "Kuebiko," literally means a "deformed man," signifying a weather-beaten, ragged scarecrow.

sen.j: また、「杖彦」が転じたものとも取れ、イザナギが黄泉から帰ってきた後の禊で杖を投げ出した時に生まれた船戸神（ふなとのかみ、岐の神、道祖神）との関連も考えられる。
sen.e: The name may also be derived from "Tsuehiko" (a man walking with a cane), which reminds us of its possible relationship with the Funatonokami god (road god) born from a cane thrown by Izanagi to clean off impurities that she brought from the land of the dead.

sen.j: 田の神、また、学業の神として信仰されており、久比古神社（石川県鹿島郡 (石川県)中能登町）や大神神社（奈良県桜井市）末社・久延彦神社などで祀られている。
sen.e: Kuebiko is worshipped as the god of paddies and also as the god of learning, and is enshrined in shrines such as Kutehiko-jinja Shrine (Nakanoto-machi, Kashima-gun, Ishikawa Prefecture) and Kuehiko-jinja Shrine, a branch shrine of Omiwa-jinja Shrine (Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).
